prevtext.line: Al Jazeera Media Network is owned by the government of Qatar.<ref name="gnprivchange">{{cite news |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/qatar/al-jazeera-turning-into-private-media-organisation-1.837871 |title=Al Jazeera turning into private media organisation |date=13 July 2011 |author=Habib Toumi |newspaper=<ahref>Gulf News</ahref> |accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="academia.edu">{{cite web |url=https://www.academia.edu/556090/The_Geopolitics_of_the_News_The_Case_of_the_Al_Jazeera_Network |title=The Geopolitics of the News: The Case of the Al Jazeera Network |author=Shawn Powers |publisher= |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="theguardian.com">[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/30/al-jazeera-independence-questioned-qatar Al-Jazeera's political independence questioned amid Qatar intervention], The Guardian</ref><ref name="lubpak.com">[http://lubpak.com/archives/39793 Deconstructing Al Jazeera and its paymasters] Let us build Pakistan</ref><ref name="bloomberg.com">[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-04-09/al-jazeera-gets-rap-as-qatar-mouthpiece.html Al-Jazeera Gets Rap as Qatar Mouthpiece] Bloomberg</ref><ref name="reuters.com">[https://www.reuters.com/video/2013/08/21/qatari-owned-al-jazeera-america-makes-it?videoId=254104873 Qatari-owned Al Jazeera America makes its debut] Reuters</ref> Al Jazeera Media Network has stated that they are editorially independent from the government of Qatar. However, this assertion is <ahref>#Editorial independence|disputed</ahref>,<ref name=guardianindep/> and some have accused Al Jazeera of being a propaganda outlet for the <ahref>Politics of Qatar|Qatari government</ahref>.<ref name="meforum.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/3147/al-jazeera |title=The Two Faces of Al Jazeera |author=Oren Kessler |work=Middle East Forum |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2014/02/19/why-egypt-hates-al-jazeera/ |title=Why Egypt Hates Al Jazeera |work=Foreign Policy |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/08/world/middleeast/qatars-support-of-extremists-alienates-allies-near-and-far.html?_r=0 |work=The New York Times |first=David D. |last=Kirkpatrick |title=Qatar's Support of Islamists Alienates Allies Near and Far |date=7 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gatestoneinstitute.org/3545/al-jazeera-extremism |title=Al Jazeera: Non-Arabs Should Not Be Fooled |author=Najat Fawzy AlSaied |work=Gatestone Institute |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/4941 |title=Al Jazeera reporter resigns over "biased" Syria coverage |work=Al Akhbar English |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/05/11/world/fahmy-al-jazeera-lawsuit/ |title=Freed Al Jazeera journalist Mohamed Fahmy sues network - CNN.com |author=Sarah El Sirgany, for CNN |date=12 May 2015 |work=CNN |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/30/al-jazeera-independence-questioned-qatar |title=Al-Jazeera's political independence questioned amid Qatar intervention |author=Dan Sabbagh |work=the Guardian |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> The network is sometimes perceived to have mainly <ahref>Islamist</ahref> perspectives, promoting the <ahref>Muslim Brotherhood</ahref>, and having a pro-<ahref>Sunni Islam|Sunni</ahref> and an anti-<ahref>Shia Islam|Shia</ahref> bias in its reporting of regional issues.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-07-10/why-does-al-jazeera-love-a-hateful-islamic-extremist- |title=Why Does Al Jazeera Love a Hateful Islamic Extremist?|access-date=2015-09-23 |date=10 July 2013 |first1=Jeffrey |last1=Goldberg |publisher=<ahref>Bloomberg L.P.</ahref> |website=bloombergview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/al-jazeera-us-government-funded-anti-muslim-brotherhood-activists-2013-7?IR=T |title=AL JAZEERA: US Government Funded Anti-Muslim Brotherhood Activists |date=10 July 2013 |work=Business Insider |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.agsiw.org/why-america-turned-off-al-jazeera/ |title=Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington - Why America Turned Off Al Jazeera - Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington |work=<ahref>Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington</ahref> |accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> However, Al Jazeera insists it covers all sides of a debate; it says it presents Israel's view, Iran's view and even aired videos released by <ahref>Osama bin Laden</ahref>.<ref>{{citation |title=Al Jazeera: The Most-Feared News Network |url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/articles/2013/06/15-al-jazeera-news-network-world-arab-eyes-telhami}}</ref> In June 2017, the Saudi, Emirati, Bahraini, and Egyptian governments demanded the closure of the news station as one of thirteen demands made to Qatar during the <ahref>2017 Qatar diplomatic crisis|2017 Qatar Crisis</ahref>.<ref>

{{cite news |last1=Thapar |first1=Karan |title=Why we should speak up for Al Jazeera |url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/why-we-should-speak-up-for-al-jazeera/article19205348.ece |accessdate=4 July 2017 |publisher=The Hindu |date=4 July 2017}}

In <ahref>Arabic language|Arabic</ahref>, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-ǧazīrah}}'' literally means "the island". However, it refers here to the <ahref>Arabian Peninsula</ahref>,<ref name="fightboredom.net">{{cite web |url=http://www.fightboredom.net/2008/02/arabic-in-graphic-design-al-jazeeras.html |title=Arabic in Graphic Design: Al Jazeera's Cartouche: "The elaborate calligraphic design spells "al-Jazeera" in Arabic, a word meaning "the island" or "the peninsula – terms used to refer to both the Arabian peninsula and the network's peninsular home state, Qatar." |date=18 February 2008 |publisher=Cloudjammer Creative Network |work=Fight.Boredom |accessdate=5 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220013533/http://www.fightboredom.net/2008/02/arabic-in-graphic-design-al-jazeeras.html |archivedate=20 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy}}
prevtext.Minus: </ref> Several other media networks have spoken out in support of the network because like its viewers, Al Jazeera presents a far more moderate, Westernized face than Islamic jihadism or rigid Sunni orthodoxy. In fact, there is very little specifically religious content in its broadcasts. Though some of its more strident critics accuse Al Jazeera of being an "Islamist" stalking horse, it is, in fact, a not-for-Prophet as well as a not-for-profit news operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/01/the-unlikely-rise-of-al-jazeera/251112/|title=The Unlikely Rise of Al Jazeera|first=Aram Bakshian|last=Jr.|publisher=}}</ref>

</ref> Several other media networks have spoken out in support of the network because like its viewers, Al Jazeera presents a far more moderate, Westernized face than Islamic jihadism or rigid Sunni orthodoxy. In fact, there is very little specifically religious content in its broadcasts. Though some of its more strident critics accuse Al Jazeera of being an "Islamist" stalking horse, it is, in fact, a not-for-Prophet as well as a not-for-profit news operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/01/the-unlikely-rise-of-al-jazeera/251112/|title=The Unlikely Rise of Al Jazeera|first=Aram Bakshian|last=Jr.|publisher=}}</ref>

current_text.lines: Al Jazeera Media Network is owned by the government of Qatar.<ref name="gnprivchange">{{cite news |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/qatar/al-jazeera-turning-into-private-media-organisation-1.837871 |title=Al Jazeera turning into private media organisation |date=13 July 2011 |author=Habib Toumi |newspaper=<ahref>Gulf News</ahref> |accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="academia.edu">{{cite web |url=https://www.academia.edu/556090/The_Geopolitics_of_the_News_The_Case_of_the_Al_Jazeera_Network |title=The Geopolitics of the News: The Case of the Al Jazeera Network |author=Shawn Powers |publisher= |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="theguardian.com">[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/30/al-jazeera-independence-questioned-qatar Al-Jazeera's political independence questioned amid Qatar intervention], The Guardian</ref><ref name="lubpak.com">[http://lubpak.com/archives/39793 Deconstructing Al Jazeera and its paymasters] Let us build Pakistan</ref><ref name="bloomberg.com">[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-04-09/al-jazeera-gets-rap-as-qatar-mouthpiece.html Al-Jazeera Gets Rap as Qatar Mouthpiece] Bloomberg</ref><ref name="reuters.com">[https://www.reuters.com/video/2013/08/21/qatari-owned-al-jazeera-america-makes-it?videoId=254104873 Qatari-owned Al Jazeera America makes its debut] Reuters</ref> Al Jazeera Media Network has stated that they are editorially independent from the government of Qatar. However, this assertion is <ahref>#Editorial independence|disputed</ahref>,<ref name=guardianindep/> and some have accused Al Jazeera of being a propaganda outlet for the <ahref>Politics of Qatar|Qatari government</ahref>.<ref name="meforum.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/3147/al-jazeera |title=The Two Faces of Al Jazeera |author=Oren Kessler |work=Middle East Forum |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2014/02/19/why-egypt-hates-al-jazeera/ |title=Why Egypt Hates Al Jazeera |work=Foreign Policy |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/08/world/middleeast/qatars-support-of-extremists-alienates-allies-near-and-far.html?_r=0 |work=The New York Times |first=David D. |last=Kirkpatrick |title=Qatar's Support of Islamists Alienates Allies Near and Far |date=7 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gatestoneinstitute.org/3545/al-jazeera-extremism |title=Al Jazeera: Non-Arabs Should Not Be Fooled |author=Najat Fawzy AlSaied |work=Gatestone Institute |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/4941 |title=Al Jazeera reporter resigns over "biased" Syria coverage |work=Al Akhbar English |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/05/11/world/fahmy-al-jazeera-lawsuit/ |title=Freed Al Jazeera journalist Mohamed Fahmy sues network - CNN.com |author=Sarah El Sirgany, for CNN |date=12 May 2015 |work=CNN |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/30/al-jazeera-independence-questioned-qatar |title=Al-Jazeera's political independence questioned amid Qatar intervention |author=Dan Sabbagh |work=the Guardian |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> The network is sometimes perceived to have mainly <ahref>Islamist</ahref> perspectives, promoting the <ahref>Muslim Brotherhood</ahref>, and having a pro-<ahref>Sunni Islam|Sunni</ahref> and an anti-<ahref>Shia Islam|Shia</ahref> bias in its reporting of regional issues.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-07-10/why-does-al-jazeera-love-a-hateful-islamic-extremist- |title=Why Does Al Jazeera Love a Hateful Islamic Extremist?|access-date=2015-09-23 |date=10 July 2013 |first1=Jeffrey |last1=Goldberg |publisher=<ahref>Bloomberg L.P.</ahref> |website=bloombergview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/al-jazeera-us-government-funded-anti-muslim-brotherhood-activists-2013-7?IR=T |title=AL JAZEERA: US Government Funded Anti-Muslim Brotherhood Activists |date=10 July 2013 |work=Business Insider |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.agsiw.org/why-america-turned-off-al-jazeera/ |title=Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington - Why America Turned Off Al Jazeera - Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington |work=<ahref>Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington</ahref> |accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> However, Al Jazeera insists it covers all sides of a debate; it says it presents Israel's view, Iran's view and even aired videos released by <ahref>Osama bin Laden</ahref>.<ref>{{citation |title=Al Jazeera: The Most-Feared News Network |url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/articles/2013/06/15-al-jazeera-news-network-world-arab-eyes-telhami}}</ref> In June 2017, the Saudi, Emirati, Bahraini, and Egyptian governments demanded the closure of the news station as one of thirteen demands made to Qatar during the <ahref>2017 Qatar diplomatic crisis|2017 Qatar Crisis</ahref>.<ref>

{{cite news |last1=Thapar |first1=Karan |title=Why we should speak up for Al Jazeera |url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/why-we-should-speak-up-for-al-jazeera/article19205348.ece |accessdate=4 July 2017 |publisher=The Hindu |date=4 July 2017}}

In <ahref>Arabic language|Arabic</ahref>, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-ǧazīrah}}'' literally means "the island". However, it refers here to the <ahref>Arabian Peninsula</ahref>,<ref name="fightboredom.net">{{cite web |url=http://www.fightboredom.net/2008/02/arabic-in-graphic-design-al-jazeeras.html |title=Arabic in Graphic Design: Al Jazeera's Cartouche: "The elaborate calligraphic design spells "al-Jazeera" in Arabic, a word meaning "the island" or "the peninsula – terms used to refer to both the Arabian peninsula and the network's peninsular home state, Qatar." |date=18 February 2008 |publisher=Cloudjammer Creative Network |work=Fight.Boredom |accessdate=5 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220013533/http://www.fightboredom.net/2008/02/arabic-in-graphic-design-al-jazeeras.html |archivedate=20 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy}}
current_text.plus: </ref> Other media networks have spoken out in support of the network. According to The Atlantic, Al Jazeera presents a far more moderate, Westernized face than Islamic jihadism or rigid Sunni orthodoxy, and though the network has been criticized as "an 'Islamist' stalking horse" it actually features "very little specifically religious content in its broadcasts".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/01/the-unlikely-rise-of-al-jazeera/251112/|title=The Unlikely Rise of Al Jazeera|first=Aram Bakshian|last=Jr.|publisher=}}</ref>

</ref> Other media networks have spoken out in support of the network. According to The Atlantic, Al Jazeera presents a far more moderate, Westernized face than Islamic jihadism or rigid Sunni orthodoxy, and though the network has been criticized as "an 'Islamist' stalking horse" it actually features "very little specifically religious content in its broadcasts".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/01/the-unlikely-rise-of-al-jazeera/251112/|title=The Unlikely Rise of Al Jazeera|first=Aram Bakshian|last=Jr.|publisher=}}</ref>
